org.catechis.legacy
Class CreateJDOMList

java.lang.Object
  org.catechis.legacy.CreateJDOMList

public class CreateJDOMList
extends java.lang.Object

The Indcot webb app uses the File, Context constructor so that it can easily log comments.

The contructor creates a document from the File, and then it's up to different methods to perfom functions on the document.

Constructor Detail

CreateJDOMList

public CreateJDOMList(java.io.File file)

Takes a file and creates a JDOM document from it.

The user then calls getElementNamed with the name of the element to retrieve a java.util.List based on the document loaded.

CreateJDOMList

public CreateJDOMList(java.io.File file,
                      java.lang.String encoding)

Takes a file and creates a JDOM document from it.

The user then calls getElementNamed with the name of the element to retrieve a java.util.List based on the document loaded.

CreateJDOMList

public CreateJDOMList(java.io.File _file,
                      javax.servlet.ServletContext _context)

This contrcutor is provided for servlet environments to enable logging.

Logging notes: context = _context; msg = file.getAbsolutePath(); context.log("CreateJDOMList file path : "+msg);

mergeWordsAndDefs

public java.util.Vector mergeWordsAndDefs(java.util.Vector list1,
                                          java.util.Vector list2)

This method assumes that the two lists are of equal length, as there should be an equal number of word-definition pairs in the file.

The problem is, the text-def elements are children of elements.

getTextDefHash

public java.util.Hashtable getTextDefHash()

getFilteredTextDefHash

public java.util.Hashtable getFilteredTextDefHash(java.lang.String test_length,
                                                  java.lang.String test_index,
                                                  java.lang.String test_levels,
                                                  java.lang.String test_type)

This method is similar to getTextDefHash, except that it filters the resutls for the desired range of words.

We need the test_name so that we can reset the index in the test file. context.log("CreateJDOMList.getFilteredTextDefHash: len-"+length+" ind-"+index);

The recordNewTestIndex method call never word. It retrieved 0 options. So we moved the index into the session scope so that the TestResultAction object, which also adds to and saves the 'name'.test file, which takes less trips to the disk anyway. The String test_name, String user_path, String encoding arguments were removed.

getFilteredTextDefHash2

public java.util.Hashtable getFilteredTextDefHash2(java.lang.String test_length,
                                                   java.lang.String test_index,
                                                   java.lang.String test_levels,
                                                   java.lang.String test_type,
                                                   java.util.Vector elt_vector)

This is a temporary method. CreateJDOMList is a lagacy object that is currently being replaced by org.catechis.JDOMSolution.

Im just adding an exclude mechanism to that words that have been tested recently can be excluded from this list.

In doing so much work these days setting up moodle which I want to integrate with, but this involves MySQL and all the messy permissions Ie been able to ignore so far.

I have to leave the safe haven of tomcat, and struts for Apache and php....

I guess this is abd adnission that that this method sucks, and I know this, but the new one, in the DailyTestAction, although threadsafe, is not scorring the tests properly now, and I just need a quick fix so that I can use the program effectively while I work in permissions hell on the other fedora core 6 box.

Its painful to even look at this method, but here goes...

unbindWord

private Word unbindWord(org.jdom.Element e,
                        java.lang.String category)

This is based on the illustrious and long suffering getFilteredTextDefHash which returned a Hashtable of words. This version requires only one word obejct, which it must first find in an xml file passed to the constructor.

At this point the developers are wishing they would have stored each word individually, but then there would be less to do the next monsoon season...

I already have a method to do this public Word getFilteredTextDefHash3(String test_length, String test_index, String test_levels, String test_type, Vector elt_vector) { context.log("CreateJDOMList.getFilteredTextDefHash3: type-"+test_type); ExcludeWord ex_time = new ExcludeWord(); Word word = new Word(); index = Integer.parseInt(test_index); int level_min = getLevelMin(test_levels); int level_max = getLevelMax(test_levels); text_def_hash = new Hashtable(); Element root = doc.getRootElement(); List word_list = root.getChildren("word"); int i = 0; int word_count = 0; int size = word_list.size(); context.log("CreateJDOMList.getFilteredTextDefHash2: words-"+size); int length = 10; // set default size but it's overridden if (test_length.equals("all")) length = size-1; else length = Integer.parseInt(test_length); boolean flag = false; int infinate = 0; while (flag==false) { if (i=size) { // loop back to 0 to look for mathing words. i = 0;index=0; if (infinate>2) { flag = true; } infinate++; } Element e = (Element)word_list.get(i); int level = getLevel(e, test_type); if (level>=level_min&&level<=level_max) { word = unbindWord(e, test_type); //try //{ boolean exclude = ex_time.checkExclusionDate(elt_vector, level, word, test_type); context.log("CreateJDOMList.getFilteredTextDefHash2: exclude-"+exclude); if (!ex_time.checkExclusionDate(elt_vector, level, word, test_type)) { log.add(ex_time.getLog()); addTextDef(e, level, index, i, word_count); word_count++; if (word_count>length) { flag=true; return word; } } //} catch (java.lang.NullPointerException npe) //{ } } else { // has level-"+level+" index-"+index+" i-"+i+" not added"); } } i++; index++; } return word; }

getWhateverHash

public java.util.Hashtable getWhateverHash(java.lang.String elements,
                                           java.lang.String names,
                                           java.lang.String values)

THis method retrieves a list of option style elements from an xml file with the following format:

elements ("word")

names content /names("text")

values content /values("definition")

/elements

THen is creates a Hash like this keys=names hash(key)=value.

                                          java.lang.String names,
                                          java.lang.String values)

THis method retrieves a list of option style elements from an xml file with the following format:

elements

names content /names

values content /values

/elements

THen is creates a vector like this "names values"

addElement

                       java.lang.String name_content,

setElement

public void setElement(java.lang.String element,
                       java.lang.String name,
                       java.lang.String name_content,
                       java.lang.String value,
                       java.lang.String value_content)

This method is used to replace the value of a child element. It's used like this:

TestResultAction.score_jdom.setElement(("option", "name", "index", "value", new_index)

It resets the index option in the user.options file so thaT the next test will start picking words where it left of the last time. Of course, this is only important with level 0 words, because higher levels either promote or demote words. This method seems pretty hopeless now, in hindsight, but remeber, I was just learning about making web apps when I wrote that. When you arent using a db, recreating primary keys cant be confusing.

recordWordScore

public void recordWordScore(java.lang.String word,
                            java.lang.String grade,
                            java.lang.String test_file,
                            java.lang.String date,
                            java.lang.String type,
                            java.lang.String max_level)

Here we create a new "test" element with grade/file/date sub-elements.

We also update each individual word level dependant on type.

Note: We cyclce thru the word list again here. It would be nice to merge this with the other previous cycle when the words are graded. Maybe this is not possible because what we use is a hashmap, no a reference to the xml file. Maybe we could bind an XPath reference to the key, or use and array...?

updateWordLevel

private void updateWordLevel(org.jdom.Element word,
                             java.lang.String pass_fail,
                             java.lang.String word_text,
                             java.lang.String date,
                             java.lang.String type,
                             java.lang.String max_level)

This method changes the 'level' element in the words file and adds the result to the word_levels Hashmap for later retrieval.

Without the updateWordLevel method, we had the levels updated an arbitrary amount of times per test, when only once was desired. It's because the test results come in as a Hastable, and we cycle trhu that hashtable looking for those words in the xml file. So for each word, we have to cycle again thru the xml file looking for that word.

There must be a better way of doing this, so the updateWordLevel method is a workaround to get things started with correct behaviour.

wordIsAlreadyUpdated

private boolean wordIsAlreadyUpdated(java.lang.String word_text)

Because we had the same words being updated numerous times, this method uses a Hashset whith the method.contains(word) to exclude further updates.

THis method should be considerd a workaround, as there is definately a better way.

getWordLevels

public java.util.Hashtable getWordLevels()

ifXDontExistCreateIt

public java.lang.String ifXDontExistCreateIt(org.jdom.Element word,
                                             java.lang.String name,
                                             java.lang.String value)

This method returns the value of the argument 'name' child element if it exists, and the argument 'value' after it creates the new child element if it doesn't. Savvy?

getListOfSpecificElementsChildren

public java.util.Vector getListOfSpecificElementsChildren(java.lang.String elements,
                                                          java.lang.String child_name,
                                                          java.lang.String value,
                                                          java.lang.String grand_child)
This method was created to get a list of the tests for a specified word. It is called in StatsWord with these args: "word", "def", word_chosen, "test" The 1st arg is the element after the root to look for. The 2nd arg is the sub-element, and the 3rd is the sub-element content The last arg is name of the specified sub-elements children. For StatsWord we returns a Vector of test elements like this: Thu Mar 03 11:21:44 PST 2005 level 0 writing.test fail

getGetDatedTestsHash

public java.util.Hashtable getGetDatedTestsHash(java.lang.String type,
                                                java.util.Vector word_test_elems)
This is an StatsWordAction specific method to return a hashtable of specific tests. We get a List of tests, and return a Hastable with the date as the key, Thu Mar 03 11:21:44 PST 2005 level 0 writing.test fail For instance, if we are looking for writing tests, then this element will become: key-Thu Mar 03 11:21:44 PST 2005 value-fail.
